name: Fundraising
description: Fundraising across these episodes is treated less as a single pitch event and more as an ongoing process of narrative-building, signal creation, and survival under uncertainty. The theme covers how founders earn conviction (or decide not to raise), how to communicate a compelling “why now” story, and how to manage runway, rejection, and investor dynamics—because capital strategy shapes product focus, hiring, speed, and ultimately company outcomes.
subtopics: Pitch narrative vs. feature pitch: how to frame a “shift in the world” and a new set of rules investors can believe in
Handling rejection and near-death rounds: resilience, iteration loops on the story, and staying alive long enough to be right
Runway and default-alive thinking: practical tactics to avoid running out of money and when to persist vs. shut down
Bootstrapping vs. venture: when profitability and constraints beat fundraising, and when raising is strategically justified
Fundraising as go-to-market leverage: using the cap table to recruit customers/advocates and accelerate distribution
Investor psychology and subjectivity: how decisions get made, what signals matter, and how founders control the narrative
common_frameworks: Strategic Narrative (Old Game → New Game; “shift in the world” / movement story)
Rejection-driven iteration (treating investor “no’s” as feedback to refine positioning and strategy)
Near-death / resilience mindset (expect repeated fundraising crises; persistence as a core founder skill)
Runway management / don’t-run-out-of-money heuristics (operate to extend time-to-learn and time-to-PMF)
Default alive vs. default dead (profitability and burn discipline as strategic optionality)
Cap table as a growth strategy (recruit investors who become customers, partners, and distribution)
